section.title: GeneSEZ JPA UML Profile
section.para: This section describes the stereotypes and the tagged values of the GeneSEZ JPA profile for UML.

To initialize the property date of class Statement with a valid value we decided to use the JPA pre-persist callback. To do so, we created a method, assigned the stereotype
jpaCallback to it and set the tagged value
prePersist to true.

Last but not least we used the stereotype
jpaAssociation on various association ends to specify cascade operations:

listitem.para: All statements are removed if the account where the statements belong to is removed. There is no reason to keep statements itself without any connection to an account.
All operations to customers are cascaded to the referenced accounts and contacts. The operations to contacts are itself cascaded to addresses.
All operations to banks are cascaded to customers. The merge and refresh operation also cascade to referenced contacts.

figure.title: GeneSEZ UML Profile for the Java Persistence API (JPA)

section.title: Stereotyp jpaPersistentEntity

listitem.para: Name of the reference in the environment naming context (ENC). Defaults to the class name. You can find the reference by using a Java naming and directory interface (JNDI) lookup.
Enables or disables optimistic locking support for entities. Default is enabled.

Is a property of the annotation @Table and specifies the name of the table for the persistent entity. To prevent naming conflicts with reserved names in the database (e.g. group) the prefix tbl_ is automatically added.
Specifies the table catalog.
Specifies the table schema.

section.title: Stereotype jpaDatatypeMapping
section.para: Allows to adjust the persistence mapping of an attribute.

listitem.para:
Allows to further specify the datatype, see the enumeration
jpaDatatype.

Is used in conjunction with the tagged value
type = jpaDatatype.TEMPORAL to specify how the values of temporal types (time and date) are stored in the database.
Specifies how enumerations are stored in the database.
Specifies if the property is mandatory or optional. The value false implies that each entity instance must have a value to this property assigned.
Specifies how data is fetched from the database.
Defines a property as transient, i.e. not persistent.

section.title: Enumeration jpaInheritanceType
section.para:
Defines the possible inheritance mapping strategies for JPA. It is the UML counterpart of the enumeration
InheritanceType of the JPA specification.

listitem.para: Indicates that a single table per class hierarchy is used to store entity objects.
A strategy in which fields that are specific to a subclass are mapped to a separate table than the fields that are common to the parent class, and a join is performed to instantiate the subclass.
A table per concrete entity class.

section.title: Enumeration jpaDatatype
section.para: Allows to further describes the mapping of the datatype of a property to the database. It is an aggregation of several JPA annotations.

listitem.para:
This annotation is the simplest type of mapping to a database column. It can be applied to a property of vaious types, including primitives, wrapper types, temporal types and any type implementing
java.io.Serializable. See the annotation
Basic of the JPA specification.

Defines a class whose instances are stored as an intrinsic part of an owning entity and share the identity of the entity. Each of the persistent properties or fields of the embedded object is mapped to the database table for the entity. See the annotation
Embeddable of the JPA specification.

Specifies that a persistent property or field should be persisted as a enumerated type. See the annotation
Enumerated of the JPA specification.

Specifies that a persistent property or field should be persisted as a large object to a database-supported large object type. It can be a binary or character type. See the annotation
Lob of the JPA specification.

This annotation must be specified for persistent fields or properties of type
java.util.Date and
java.util.Calendar. See the annotation
Temporal of the JPA specification.

section.title: Enumeration jpaTemporalType
section.para:
Specifies how temporal types (time and date) specifically
java.util.Date and
java.util.Calendar are stored within the database. It is the UML counterpart of the enumeration
TemporalType of the JPA specification.

listitem.para:
Map as
java.sql.Date.

Map as
java.sql.Time.

Map as
java.sql.Timestamp.

section.title: Enumeration jpaEnumType
section.para:
Specifies how enumeration literals are stored in the database. It is the UML counterpart of the enumeration
EnumType of the JPA specification.

listitem.para: Persist enumerated type property or field as an integer, i.e. the ordinal value of the enumeration literal.
Persist enumerated type property or field as a string, i.e. the string representation of the enumeration literal.

section.title: Enumeration jpaFetchType
section.para:
Specifies how data is fetched from the database. It is the UML counterpart of the enumeration
FetchType of the JPA specification.

listitem.para: Defines that data must be fetched eagerly, i.e. when an entity object is fetched from the database.
Defines that data can be fetched lazily, i.e. when the data is needed and not necessarily when the entity object is fetched from the database.
